- More structured than your average startup (in terms of formal reviews, HR, etc.) 
- Highly aspirational (wants to become the next Google or Facebook)
cons:
- Quantcast is going through major growing pains, including multiple reorgs that have caused instability in the customer facing orgs driven by new sales leadership, who all come to Quantcast because they know someone. They, in turn, bring their friends to fill senior roles without having much context in the industry. 
- Products are constantly being released without being tested, causing tension between sales and product/engineering. 
- Everyone is more than willing to point the finger at another team when something is wrong, instead of working together to fix it.
- Mediocrity is rewarded, especially for folks who are highly political. Middle management is really young, and many managers have no interest in learning the products or in learning to manage. It's easy to get away with doing the bare minimum.
- Despite all of Quantcast's boasting about being the next Facebook or Google, our benefits don't even include 401k matching.

headline: Great place to work overall, mid-management could improve
pros: Overall I've had a very positive experience at Quantcast. Compared to other companies I've worked for, the people here stand out as being especially smart, kind, and motivated to help the company succeed. Since arriving at QC, I've felt empowered as an individual contributor to notice a problem and take on a project to fix it. Personally, I've observed that taking initiative like this is applauded and generally rewarded. This certainly does not happen 100% of the time but it is much more common than at the two other tech companies I've worked for.
cons:
The main criticism I have is that there can be a lot of disorganization on high level initiatives that seems to stem from poor communication at the mid-manager level. It seems that managers on various teams do not talk to each other enough and there ends up being overlapping work or poor execution due to a misunderstanding of how another team operates. It's frustrating to find yourself in the middle of this and discover some work you were doing is not going to be used because the manager wasn't doing their job.

Another strong criticism is that there is no 401k matching at all. I like Quantcast but refusing to provide any 401k matching just isn't classy. As another reviewer pointed out, Quantcast cannot claim to be on par with companies like Facebook and Google without this.

headline: Customer Success Review
pros: Free Food, Decent Pay, Fun crowd for those in their 20's
cons: The company has invested too much in using 3rd party software instead of developing its own internal tools. My boss asked for feedback regarding how to make processes more efficient, but when I provided it my boss felt I was complaining. There is too much responsibility on the Customer Success Division since the reorganization. The Account Executive and Account Manager will not do their jobs or give you misinformation, but the Customer Success Specialist is blamed for their mistakes. Your job requires dealing with all day fire drills.

headline: Senior Account Executive
pros: Great team and culture with excellent pay and benefits.
cons: Too myopic on mature markets, not willing to take risks on emerging markets and verticals.

headline: So glad I work at Quantcast!
pros: Super-smart colleagues.  Fun work environment.  Beautiful new SF offices.  Well-positioned in the ad tech space for profitable growth.
cons: Quantcast is relatively unknown outside of our industry.  It is not yet a household name.

headline: Great Place to learn
pros:
- Great working environment  
- Smart colleagues 
- Cutting edge technology
cons: - Would be great to get matching 401k

headline: Growth, growth and growth
pros:
- Very bright and intelligent people, high bar for hiring 
- Focus on employee growth. Managers are responsible for growing employees 
- Engineering focused. Engineers are always put first 
- Perks, free food, bar in the new office, happy hours, parties, etc.
cons:
- Onboarding is hard, the ad-tech era is full of acronyms and new terms, and Quantcast is also full of internal names and codenames, many of them deprecated but documents are still lying around so a new employee has a really hard time understanding wtf is going on
- Employer branding: Quantcast's size and scale is unmatched, and the company is doing great, but it's only known to insider and not many people outside of Quantcast know about this.

headline: Great Workplace
pros: Great place to work. people are smart, care and hardworking.
cons: can be a contentious environment if you get people from the wrong teams together at times.

headline: Client Service Specialist
pros:
Great culture and young, dynamic work environment. 
Colleagues are bright. 
Free lunches!
cons:
Sometimes you could feel overwhelmed by the workload, particularly at the end of each month. 
Too many changes, too little time to adapt.

headline: There are worse places to work
pros: Good smart people that are easy to work with within the team. Individual engineers can be great. People are chill
cons: People are nice off the job. On the job culture between teams can be suffocating. There is a tendency to be bogged down by legacy tech

headline: Sales manager
pros:
- best product in market 
- confidence in senior management 
- great growth opportunities
- putting clients first
- chance to work with and learn from incredibly smart and talented people
cons:
- clunky systems
- improve global collaborations

headline: Comp could be better
pros: good people you work alongside, perks are on par with other tech companies, weekly sales enablement sessions, product typically works and does what you sell
cons: quotas are somewhat arbitrary based on team and manager, growth and bonuses are limited, the advertising industry is a sort of "old boys" network where its about schmoozing client a bit more than selling value

headline: Agency sales manager
pros: Great product. Unique positioning in the market. Huge engineering team is taking the business to the next level. Plenty of team building events
cons: Lack of progression. Expectations are over zealous. Management keep the floor out the loop when it comes to what is going on in the business.

headline: Great time to join but expect some growing pains
pros: Great company to join at a pivotal time in its growth trajectory. Employees are incredibly smart and collaborative, office perks are great - free catered lunch and dinner daily, weekly happy hours - and (most) leadership is open to your opinion and thoughts, you just have to take the initiative.
cons: Since the company is moving from boot-strapped startup to real "big boy" company, there's bound to be growing pains. A lot of management change has been tough to weather for many, lots of starts and stops. I think we're headed in the right direction but it'll take some time to hit a stride, just hope we don't lose too many on the way.

headline: badly run private company
pros:
- free food
- prime office location in the city center
cons:
- no room for any meaningful career progression (over the last three years 2 people got promoted internally in Dublin. The company prefers hiring external profiles with zero relevant industry experience or with questionable reputations).
- sales product training role has been open for more than a year which is proof that the company doesn't invest in training and development. There are also no indications that the role will be back-filled anytime soon.
- lack of support and investments in non-core territories (non-UK). There is for example no trade marketing budget available for emerging markets - full stop.
- very weak middle management that prefers bullying tactics over open and constructive dialogue with the people that are in the trenches.
- zero strategy planning.
- slacker culture (specifically among middle managers).
- very bleak outlook when looking at a possible IPO (no headcount to grow the bottom-line, massive client churn, no self-service product...)
- the QC technology stack is a clear acquisition target but a potential acquirer doesn't need the trading desk that QC has bolted on top of this technology. If an acquisition happens it will come with massive lay-offs and/or a big restructuring.

headline: Think long and hard
pros: The people are great. It's a place you won't mind going every day. There are some really smart people here and everyone is so nice. There are some great perks and we are looked after well.
cons: There is nowhere to go once you're in the door. After a number of years observing people in here it is clear that progression is not high on the list. We're focused on getting money in the door and prepping for an IPO, that we forget that the reason we're able to do these things is because of the people. As a company we "talk" about progression, but in fact unless you're on someone's good side it will never happen. We also hang onto to poor employees far to long.

headline: Customer Success
pros: Lots of perks, new office coming, great food, flexibility, fun people. The role is a great starting point. As someone with only a few years of experience, the role has taught me a ton about digital advertising and is setting me up for next steps in my career. Quantcast's product works and clients are happy. My team is supportive and I love coming to work everyday.
cons: The role is entry level so there are a few things that come with it that aren't glamorous but that comes with the territory.

headline: Customer Success = Awful
pros: Start up perks like beer cart, happy hours, snacks and laid back attire.
cons: Unfortunately I'm still trapped in this role as a Senior Customer Success Specialist. Tenure is short here and I've seen so many good people go. Due to the company's reorg the CSS role was created and the responsibilities are to carry out the 'behind the scenes' work around campaign build and setup. When things go sour the CSS is the first one to be blamed. Lack of support from leads and no accountability. No one complains to upper management and it's all done behind their backs. Would not recommend anyone for this role.

headline: Quantcast Review
pros: It's great, I've been working here for over 5 years and had a lot of growth opportunities. Smart people willing to help you tackle large problems.
cons: Current office is getting crowded, though the upcoming move to a new office may help with this. Although we're getting to a good size (900 people) we're still not as well known as many other engineering companies.

headline: Great people; Awesome CEO; working on tooling
pros: Lots of really smart people including a lot of recent success hiring very senior engineers who are making a huge impact.  Great business outlook, and an incredibly smart executive team focussed on doing the right thing.
cons: Tooling for software engineers (think configuration management, deployment infrastructure, monitoring infrastructure) hasn't scaled with the company and we're currently investing in making that stuff really good.  The transition has been a bit of a slog

headline: Great company to work for!
pros:
- Great compensation and benefits
-The CEO holds frequent all-hands meetings to constantly keep us in the loop.
- Senior management cares deeply about all employees.
- Lots of training and resources, with an opportunity to always be learning.
- The company is full of smart and friendly people, and strives to protect our great culture as we continue to grow.
cons: - None that I can think of! I love working at Quantcast!

headline: Great growing AdTech company in Austin
pros: Great, open culture where you can be yourself and the people are so friendly. There's so much opportunity to make an impact here in Austin culturally and professionally as Quantcast is growing its presence here in ATX. The leadership team is growing and getting stronger. Free lunches, group workout sessions, team outings are great perks. Employee benefits, 401k options, great maternity leave with ramp back period, etc show they truly care about their employees and take feedback seriously.
cons: It's a big organization, so as long as leadership stays open and transparent and communicates well with the team, things will continue to be great.

headline: Great company with purpose, vision and smarts
pros:
The opportunity to work within a dynamic and evolving platform driven by smart, energetic and innovative tech professionals. 

The opportunity to be part of building something special from the ground up, where there's still plenty of room to make a huge impact on the company and the industry. 

Great leadership that's willing to work hard to attract more great talent, expand into new markets and invest in the technology and marketing communities.
cons: Getting comfortable with being uncomfortable in a rapidly evolving space. That's not really a con, but not everyone is comfortable with the tech space and pace of change.

headline: The company needs some serious introspection.
pros: The company has a great core product and I think has the opportunity to grow into an even bigger player in the real-time bidding market.
cons: As an engineer, you definitely won't get market rate pay unless you're Staff level. There is a lot of dead weight in terms of teams, projects, and lousy people that should just be trimmed. The company has been hemorrhaging top engineering talent for a long time and it's only going to keep getting worse as teams are trying to do too much for the talent they have left. Tooling for engineering teams basically doesn't exist, so teams end up implementing a lot of things themselves, all differently of course. Teams don't communicate effectively across the engineering org. Engineering leadership doesn't communicate effectively. Nobody communicates effectively.

headline: Interesting place -
pros: Interesting work, smart and fun coworkers
cons: Teams focus on their own things, so if you are trying to change something other teams own, it could take a while (esp. if it involves offices in Europe and Asia).

headline: Intern Interview
pros: Everyone was very nice even with the tough questions.
cons: Everyone was so nice, you don't know how well you are actually doing

headline: Awesome place to work!
pros: The people and culture are unbeatable. Good work/life balance is enjoyable. Competitive compensation and good benefits. Great company values, a lot of thought going in everything being done at the company; open culture: visibility and accessibility to management. I've worked at a lot of places in my 10+ year work history and this is one of the best.
cons: No cons. Come ready to roll up your sleeves and work with super smart people.

headline: Could & Should Be So Much Better
pros: Great product & message that the market is very receptive to.  Talented and engaging middle management who has a desire to invest in and develop their people.  There is a desire to continuously evolve the product, and change with the market.  Great set of tools & resources for people to do their job well & succeed.  Great benefits & solid workplace perks.
cons: A very micro-managed sales culture that stems from the Senior Sales Management team.  Very old school and outdated management style from the way people are managed down to the metrics & expectations.  This begins with less than accurate expectations set through the interview process.  The culture in most offices is not a very lively one, and one where there is a "head down" attitude.  Management gets in their people's way by trying to take away individuality and promote a machine like "one-size fits all" environment.  Not enough internal promotion at the management level.  The pay is very much below industry & tech standards.  Engineering is the only department that is valued.  This company could and should be so much better, but management gets in their own way.  The company thrives in spite of these failures.

headline: Great Culture
pros:
I've only been with the company for a short time, but it's already one of the best places I've ever worked. 

The company is filled with truly talented people who want to build a great culture. I've never seen so much employee initiative in organizing clubs, social activities, and volunteering events. 

Quantcast reinforces this by investing a lot into employee happiness (happy hours, catered meals, corporate outings, team building, onboarding events, etc.) and upper management seems to genuinely care that everyone feels like they are a part of the team and helping to build something great. 

As an example, the CEO still takes time to personally talk to all new hires, which is crazy for a 800+ employee, global company. I met him quickly at a remote office and when I was visiting the corporate headquarters, he remembered me and stopped what he was doing to have a conversation with me in the hall. That would have been unheard of at any of my previous employers.
cons: The company is growing very quickly and with that comes growing pains. In trying to create scalable best practices, new technologies and processes are attempted and sometimes quickly abandoned or changed, which can create confusion.

headline: quantitative analyst
pros: good research experience working there
cons: no much time for myself

headline: Mileage may vary
pros:
-Some really terrific people work here, by in large Quantcast tends to hire really amazing people that I suspect I'll be friends with for a while.
-Interesting product, rather robust
cons:
-Depending on what department you're in, I don't recommend it.  Managers are ill equipped to train you, and incredibly hands off - to the point where you're regularly wondering were they are.
-Contradictory culture/behavior.  This is probably due to this being a marketing company, so they market themselves well. Unfortunately, I found things to not be as they seemed.
-Too many meetings that don't seem productive
-Great lack of transparency

headline: Great culture!
pros:
Quantcast has a very collaborative, fun, and supportive environment. I love the culture here and that you're given opportunities to make a difference to improve both the product and culture at Quantcast. Management is very transparent and continually make strategic decisions that are ultimately best for the future of the Company. I truly respect and admire Konrad's leadership and his ability to maintain open communication on a consistent basis.  

Free lunch, dinner and snacks are always a bonus. 

Quantcast has also made recent improvements to improve Maternity leave and career pathing. This type of personal support and professional development is another instance of the strong culture at Quantcast.
cons: Typical growing pains. Sometimes processes seem unnecessarily complicated as we continue to grow.

headline: Senior Client Strategist
pros: Great technology, smart people, amazing perks, stock options, free breakfast, lunch and dinner.
cons: Junior management, below average salary

headline: A lot of talented people
pros: Being in quantcast, I was working in advertising product, A lot of talented people working in their. Compare with working in bigger company, it's more fun and interesting
cons:
Don't know when will IPO.
Also hiring speed is not enough for business growing.

headline: It's make or break time
pros:
- Phil has a great vision which will hopefully be actualised this year
- If you have a good manager you can have a fairly flexible schedule and work from home at times
- Perks are incredible, free food all day, after work drinking, travel
- New offices across the board
cons:
- The teams are confused about how to drive the products and what they actually have to sell 
- HR is awful, make sure to check your contract is right and if you ever need a Visa - do it yourself
- You have to develop yourself
- A lot of pointless management that never make any decisions
- No real career growth

headline: Great culture, goals, people.
pros:
Wonderful, smart, fun people who get a lot done. Many like to hang out often after work. 
Lean teams, which mean you'll get to learn and do so much here. 
Technologies and scale that impress people inside and outside the company. 
Many things don't have a process in place, so if you make a good case to your manager, you can probably get it. 
Business continues to grow constantly, so it's exciting to be part of. 
Culture is built ground-up. Employees start traditions instead of management sponsoring things they think people will like. 
Not much politics. 
A lot of employees have been here many years. This is impressive for a small company in this market. 
Spends money carefully.
cons: The office isn't as nice as other tech companies in the area, but we're moving to a new office in a few months which should address this. Salaries are lower than some other companies. All these things are probably on purpose though. A lot of people respect executive leadership for not buying into the hype and taking in more funding just because other companies are doing it.

headline: Smart people, fun environment, great benefits, organisational mess.
pros: Lovely smart people to work with and learn from. Free food and benefits a big plus and a nice office social culture with team events and after work drinks.
cons: Roles are poorly defined and management always seems to be struggling to sort things out. As soon as things start to stabilise, there's always another severe shift or radical change of game from upper management. Seniors and mid levels hired from outside organisation so no real progression opportunities. All real talent leaves. Company Means well, but organisational mess.

headline: Great people, great products and great culture
pros:
A learning culture based on respect.
Great Management. The CEO and President are rock stars. They are not only smart but decent caring people.
cons: Company is growing rapidly so there are problems but that is expected. The company needs to try and keep its tenured people longer.

headline: Day to day can be great; organizational structure is severely lacking
pros:
Free lunch and dinner - we just got a healthier caterer, so the food's now even higher-quality than it was before.

Teammates - depending on which team you're on, you can spend your entire day working with brilliant, friendly people.

The product - people at Quantcast joke that we all drank the Kool-Aid when we started, but we really do have an excellent product, and people at QC are genuinely excited about maintaining the quality of what we sell.

Collaboration - QC has very little in the way of office politics. There will always be some, but the vast majority of people here have no interest in manipulating or stabbing you in the back in order to get ahead. We're all working towards the same goal, and most people you interact with will be highly supportive of you.
cons:
The re-org - it's been mentioned in other reviews, but there was recently a re-org of the entire sales/client operations side of the business, and it's gone terribly. There's a lot of bitterness and a lot of attrition, particularly from top performers.

Attrition - in general, people stay at Quantcast an average of about two years, which means that we tend to cycle behaviors every two years as well, since nobody is around to remind us that we already tried something and either failed/didn't like it.

Middle management - having a good manager can make or break your career at Quantcast. If you have a good manager, they will look out for your career growth, advocate for you, and help you find your passions. If you have a bad manager, you will have no idea how you're doing until you hit annual review, at which point it will be too late for you to make any changes that can affect your chances of a promotion or raise.

Money - we're underpaid. The fact that we have catered food helps soften it, though.

Workload - we're trying to scale while keeping headcount low, which means that everybody is stretched thin while we figure out how to become more efficient. This will probably last a while.

headline: Fun place to work when surrounded by great coworkers
pros: People are very intelligent and also fun to work with. If working with data and/or ad tech is your thing, Quantcast is a great place to be. Growth opportunities vary from department to department (both a pro and a con).
cons: Growth opportunities vary from department to department (both a pro and a con). Everyone is underpaid, and badly executed re-org recently seems to have resulted in more unhappy people than normal

headline: Software engineering intern
pros: Wonderful mix of cutting-edge technology, great people, great compensation. Small enough to be placed on important projects but large enough to be part of a sizable organization.
cons: A company growing as fast as Quantcast is bound to have some growing pains. Many administrative decisions were made with a smaller group in mind.

headline: Lots of Great People!
pros: There are some great people, with fascinating challenges as the company grows and grows.  Quantcast is a profitable growing company with great top-side potential.
cons: The newly imported Amazon culture.  A competitive culture is growing to supplant the collaborative one.  Pay is on the low side for the industry.

headline: Major Hidden Organizational Issues
pros:
As many of the other reviews mention, lots of smart and capable people.  Interesting problem space and intellectual approaches to solutions. 

Fun happy hours.
cons:
The engineering culture seemed reminiscent of the much debated culture of amazon, in which everyone down to the individual contributor level must take responsibility of development work, QA, hiring, product management, client support, requirement gathering, and prioritization of multiple projects. It felt like the engineers were stretched far too thin which in turn created not only bad products but large waves of attrition. 

Also, they seem to have difficulty with appropriate resource allocation, in that they assign people to projects that don't cater to their strengths or approve teams who insist on spending their work hours building and supporting crazy things outside the scope of adTech (think Atlassian products...).   The lack of organization between product, client support, and engineering made it very hard to get anything done here. I hope they have since or will change their methods.

headline: Great Vison; Poor Execution and Middle Management
pros: Some of the smartest people around work at Quantcast. Their engineering and data science teams are truly top notch and solving some really interesting challenges. The landscape of ad tech will continue to evolve and there is about to be a blood bath as the Lumascape quickly narrows as most of their competitors run out of cash and close their doors or end up as acquisition targets.
cons: Ego....everyone else doesn't have to be doing it wrong.  Believe it or not, there are other approaches that make sense and what they are really doing is avoiding uncomfortable topics such as pricing, margin, mix of tactics etc. They are playing the game just like almost every adtech company to game the attribution model only they are going to point the finger at the same time while retargeting the crap out of the so called "prospecting campaigns".

headline: Growing Company With Plenty Of Opportunity
pros: Strong executive management group that has built a killer product and assembled a capable core of managers to lead the various teams.  Opportunities carve define your own career path  Talented group of colleagues that constantly challenge one another to get better.
cons: Company direction is a little heavy handed in borrowing from Google's org structure.  Sales team comes across as a little boiler-room esque resulting in a slightly fratty atmosphere.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great Staff, friendly and open office. Always a great atmosphere.
cons: Long hours are the norm.

headline: Great Company!
pros: Quantcast is a great company that strives to make sure its employees enjoy coming to work each day. They constantly evaluate the way they are doing things and try to improve any areas where they feel they might be falling short. Its a company that is open to innovation and is transparent about the why/how of decisions.
cons: Implementing change, while sometimes it can be frustrating especially in the middle, is a great thing in the long run.

headline: Super collaborative and intelligent coworkers
pros: Everyone at Quantcast wants to be helpful and make a difference. If you have a question for the CEO, you can ask the CEO. There are no off-limit people and everyone is sociable, particularly every Friday during Beer Cart. There is a beer cart (with wine and food) every Friday from 4 onwards. Whiskey is for Wednesday. Monday has Noah's Bagels for breakfast. The people at Quantcast are really happy to be at Quantcast.
cons: Current office space is reaching limits for company, but that is being rectified this year (2016). Some issues with current space: 1) not enough small conference rooms for impromptu meetings, 2) not enough phone rooms for making recruiting calls, 3) lounge isn't big enough for all employees at once (this is where regular company meetings are held).

headline: Great company
pros: Great culture. People are all extremely intelligent. Easy to work cross departmentally. Free food. The Quantcast advertise solution works.
cons: No reimbursement for health and wellness. No 401K match.

headline: Company with great challenges, but poor execution
pros:
* Interesting problems to solve
* Lots of data to deal with
* Really smart people
cons:
* Too many layers of management, territorial managers
* Little room for growth
* Too much emphasis on hiring people, but not caring about people who are already there
* Incompetent people with loud voices get further
* Little interest/apprecation for trying out new things

headline: Corporate Sales - Account Executive
pros:
Unique product in the space, highly respected reputation in AdTech, and can climb the ladder of promotions fairly quickly. 

Great place to close large deals with big brands - and ultimately develop a stellar sales resume.
cons:
Compensation is terribly sub-par compared to competitors in our space - both large and small. You sell at quantcast to sell a great product, build a book, and gain promotions. 

You dont come to sell at Quantcast to make money.

headline: Great company
pros:
- all the perks of a start-up
- fun location in the city
- the employees are smart, energetic, and willing to pitch in
cons:
- not as supportive of allowing for remote office work
- management in NYC office is disconnected from the reality of Silicon Valley
- still haven't gone public

headline: Violent Re-Orgs to No End
pros: Lots of free food. Ability to have a fairly flexible work structure. Competitive salary when compared to similar tech companies.
cons: Growing pains of a start up. Lack of clarity on anyone's roles and responsibilities, all the way up to senior management. Love to hire from outside and leave current employees stunted.

headline: Manager
pros: Very smart and talented group of people. Work hard, play hard mentality. Quantcast is growing by leaps and bounds, and for the most part, is doing this graciously. They also provide decent benefits, free lunch and dinner (cold breakfast as well), snacks, drinks, beer, wine, etc.
cons: No 401k matching, some employees are paid a decent amount under market value (others are on par), not clear paths career growth.

headline: Corp Sales
pros: Good culture, fun place to work, great product, and solid leadership.
cons: Lack of direction around career planning and limited growth opportunities. Many sales people under paid and dissatisfied with compensation. A lot of turn over post 2 year mark.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Perks are great, smart executive leadership, great product and internal systems for managing campaigns, access to resources, good culture.
cons: Limited opportunities for growth. Compensation a bit below other ad tech companies.

headline: Work in Progress
pros:
- Employee Benefits
- Free Food
- Good co-workers (for the most part)
cons:
- Poor Money Management
- Lack of support for departments not Sales or Engineering

headline: Campaign Analyst
pros: Fun and young culture, quick to adapt to change and address issues that are identified, Quantathon is a great event, great executive management team, open and transparent culture
cons: Control is unevenly distributed within the Sales & Support teams, structure does not easily lend one to take vacation or sick days

headline: Operations
pros: People are great to work with. Every department has some ultra competent members. Structurally, the organisation is set up well to be very responsive. You can escalate problems and they do get read even if they don't always get acted upon. Automation and internal tools within the company are fantastic, meaning that roles can evolve with tedious tasks being absorbed by automated processes more and more leaving more time for all team members to focus on strategy. Engineering department is accessible, friendly, and rock solid in terms of capability. They're the best in attitude and performance.
cons: Sales isn't goaled effectively so that they are set up to work against members of operations teams in cases that aren't that infrequent. Operations previously had a significant problem promoting from within and retaining key members of the team, but efforts have been made to remedy this. Ability to transition to different roles within the organization is extremely difficult. Some teams in operations are too heavily leaned upon, but it seems efforts have been made to correct this with increased headcount. Comp is comparatively low for the vertical.

headline: Great company with lots of room for growth
pros: Love the smaller but entrepreneurial culture. Given Quantcast's current growth and reputation in the industry, its an exciting time to be a part of this company. I came from a larger tech company, so when I came to Quantcast I loved the autonomy and the ability to really make an impact. There is also a lot of room for growth and a fast-paced career trajectory.
cons: They don't have an office is Silicon Valley area, but are expected to expand there (from what i've heard).

headline: Up
pros: Industry leading tech with competitive advantage on the market. Work on interesting challenges. High growth. Fun culture. Decent travel opportunities.
cons: The lunch line is a high stress experience. Longer hours. Highly competitive industry. More work than there are people.

headline: Good but not perfect
pros: Great product. It works which makes it an easy sell, free lunches and great training make it a pleasure when getting started.
cons: There is a large hierarchy when starting out so don't expect a quick promo if you already have tons of experience. There is an extremely high turnover of staff.

headline: Terrific company, especially for new grads or sr managers
pros: Innovative, growing company with solid senior leadership and smart people overall. Typical tech perks like catered lunches and dinners, stocked kitchens, ping pong and pool tables, nap hammocks, etc.
cons: Limited opportunity for career advancement, below market base salaries in the Bay Area's absurdly expensive housing market. Great place for someone beginning their career or for senior managers, less so for those that have several years of experience but are not senior management level.

headline: Excellent Internship Program
pros: Internship program is well-managed - a few fun off-sites and good community among co-workers. Work component was excellent. Interns are provided with both a leader/mentor who oversees the project and a sort of "buddy" who provides day-to-day help and camaraderie. Internship was an excellent learning experience, as my mentor put a lot of effort into giving me an achievable but challenging product with real impact - something I could be proud of. Also, free food.
cons: Quantcast sports fairly decent facilities, but doesn't quite rival the absurdity (read: Odawalla smoothies - I'm looking at you, Google) of creature comforts that one might find at a big-name tech company. Overall, for a ~700-person company, I found the perks provided to be excellent.

headline: If a friend were interviewing, I'd advise them not to
pros: I would say the best thing about the job were the people and the free food. Also did a couple of trips abroad with the company, which was fun.
cons: The goals and targets of each team are misaligned even though they're all working towards the same goal i.e. creating value for the shareholder. It's a basic problem that was flagged to management over and over again and nothing was done because managers were so much more interested in their own advancement. I know that there is an element of this in all companies but at Quantcast it really felt as though this would be their undoing. Also, there is very little focus on career advancement and the sales team has one woman and ten men.

headline: Full of talent and potential
pros:
Great benefits
Free lunch and snacks
Lots of talented, motivated employees
Company encourages employees to think outside of the box
cons:
Work hours can vary significantly
Typical growing pains of a startup-occasional turnover, large scale system changes

headline: Account Executive

headline: Great Place for Sales Growth

Good opportunities to expand your role and take on leadership roles or find new opportunities as you advance. Current leadership is a dedicated group with vision
cons:
Below average salary for the market and San Francisco itself. There is some balance when factoring in total compensation, but don't expect the base (or initial base + bonus) to blow you away. They are strong at recognizing and rewarding hard work and achievement, but in between these periods there is limited opportunity to "blow your number away" and pull in a large bonus

headline: Great leadership - motivate & challenge

headline: Good But Lacking Competencies Required For Greatness
pros:
Fun, happy work environment in exciting industry.

Filled with a lot of great people and personalities.

Product is excellent. Great reputation. Major adtech player with a very bright future.

CEO amongst other executives lead by example and are respected.

In general, it's a great place to work.
cons:
Lack of authority and accountability: 

We reward people that go beyond what's asked of them. We reward people for good, positive behavior, however, when it comes to people NOT doing their job, NOT doing what's asked or expected of them and NOT acting appropriately, there is a complete lack of consequences and accountability.

Example: Leadership asks the entire organization to use a tool to communicate. Only half the people use it and the rest disregard request with no repercussion or worry of authority. 

Lack of communication:

We under-communicate, both across departments and vertically. The channels to communicate aren't defined along as are the expectations as to who should be communicating. Everything, whether we added a new executive to the team, added a new feature to the product, or announced a major partnership is under-communicated from top to bottom and side to side. Leads to a whole lot of confusion, miscommunication and hearsay.

Example: Major partnership formed or key executive joins/leaves company with little to no announcement made to the entire organization either via email or another means.

headline: Great people, great culture, interesting problems, and a bright future.

headline: Stellar Company

headline: Lots of work, no recognition, and zero work-life balance
pros:
Free food (this is used to tie you to your desk for 10 hours). 
Great introduction into the programmatic space.
Friday afternoon beer cart.
cons:
You will be required to work from at least 8-6 every day. If you leave before 6pm, you get stares of death from everyone around.
You can hear a needle drop most days in the office and "fun" really isn't permitted. They love to pretend like everyone has fun, but as soon as you do it's seen as "goofing off".
The interview process was absurd - throughout they will compare themselves to Google and after a gauntlet of phone interviews, they will bring you in for a 4-6 hour day interview where you will meet with at least 4-6 different people. They will then five you a taxing "homework assignment" that they will expect you to complete by the next day (i.e. stay up all night after your current day job to complete). If they like you, they will then give you an exam of some kind and have you come back in to give a presentation.
Very little room to be yourself and have a personality. If you have weekly commitments outside of work, get ready to miss them. Your manager will complain to their bosses that you are not a "team player" and you'll most likely be reprimanded and/or fired.

headline: Great Company.  Brightest people in the industry. Engineering Centric.  Lacking in communication structure & management.

headline: Fun times, interesting challenges.
pros: The people are a lot of fun and the work is very interesting. I've learned an incredible amount there, and feel like I'm meaningfully contributing to the products. The food is good, and it's fairly easy to maintain a good work-life balance.
cons: It's online advertising, you're not exactly curing cancer.

headline: Great culture, disruptive technology, fun place to work and grow your career.
pros:
* Smart people (even the non-engineers are pretty smart) who are also nice. Very little toxicity beyond standard communication challenges.
* Great leadership who are committed to building a long term company and exceptional value in the marketplace.
* Excellent culture - strong emphasis on training & development, catered lunches/dinners, ping-pong/foos/pinball/pool, beer brewing competition, beer cart Fridays, annual competition to present new ideas to senior executives (and win $$ and stock options), good benefits.
* Pre-IPO stage with every opportunity to contribute to the growth of a company that is creating serious disruption in a 100+ yr old industry.
cons:
* With a collaborative and "nice" startup culture comes communication issues (passive-aggressiveness, unresolved conflict) and over-reliance on consensus (which can lead to death by meeting).
* Startup related issues: some cross-departmental relationships could be better, career development paths could be more clear.

headline: Good career growth opportunities but a very high-strung workplace
pros: Quantcast tries to recognize your achievements, and even more, if you are engineers. So far, Quantcast seems receptive to employees’ feedback. It has a learning culture which is a great environment to be exposed to many different things for the curious mind.
cons: There is a lack in sense of accountability. The observed tendency is to try to assign blame to someone when things go wrong. This attitude brews buried unhealthy hostility toward people you work with. Another con is that if you are non-engineers, you do feel like second-class citizens a lot of the times.

headline: Outstanding place to work!
pros: Great products that work, proprietary data sets that differentiate the company from the noise in the marketplace.  Intelligent team members across the board.  World class training for the entire organization (sales training is comprehensive and like nothing I have ever seen at other companies).  Great career growth potential in an exciting and breakout industry.
cons: Normal challenges in a hyper-growth environment.  Adding A LOT of new people each month which is not a con, just creates challenges of integration and getting people up to speed.

headline: Engineering culture, smart, ethical and cutting edge.
pros: Great products, fun culture and always looking for ways to innovate. Lots of smart people and opportunity for those looking to learn about adtech and grow their career. Quantcast is unique in that it captures first party data in real time to build complex targeting models rather than leverage third party data like most competitors do in this space. Work hard, play hard. We build great products and services around  them.
cons: A little conservative for your typical start up culture. Not overly communicative on long term strategy or financial numbers.

headline: Joining Quantcast was one of my better decisions.
pros:
Frightfully smart people work here, but they do so with far less attitude than usually accompanies that. The quality of the people who work here, professionally and personally, is one of the things that makes me look forward to going into work each day. The people are not just smart people, they're good people.

The technical challenges are considerable. There are a lot of tricky problems to solve here. This is very cool.

The management is clearly trying to build a long-running concern (not a pump-and-dump startup), with constant attention to continually improving how they do business. The management appears genuinely concerned about providing ongoing career growth (and rewarding it). This is a more "grown-up" start up than many: with much of the playfulness, but less of the actual insanity I've noted so much of elsewhere.

I love the catered lunch--not just for the nutritious, mostly yummy food, but for the easy opportunity to socialize with clever, funny, friendly people.
cons:
The growing population of employees means you may need to wait for the bathroom. ;)

The usual growing pains associated with a start-up, including hiccups when balancing cost-control and expansion, or when scaling organizational structures as the company grows. I do think we're mostly doing a good job here.

Sometimes the workload is a bit much (see: "start-up"), but we are trying to hire....

There could be more transparency about the organizational structure. It can be hard to figure out what group works on what and where to find them.

We make money in marketing, which is less cool than making money in building solar panels or curing cancer.

headline: Do not join unless you're an engineer. You will be set up for failure.
pros: Great product! Free food, dinner and weekly happy hour. Nice office location. Pretty much it stops there.
cons: Lack of leadership and management is a mess. Long daily hours and weekends. No work life balance at all and lack of support from managers. There is no professional with other department. Sales, finance and CS team is a mess. There is no support with other department but mostly the blame game. There is a huge lack of corporate processes which should be consistence, effective, accuracy and timely. Everything is manual and pretty much broken. I was trained to email Sales and Finance and just wait for something to happen. It's a black-hole because I am constantly not meeting my client's request and target due to others delay action. Making it impossible to build new or retain client relations. It was a dead end place for me.

headline: Great technology, not so great management.
pros: The technology stack is impressive. As an engineer you will work with some leading edge technology and some brilliant people. The Friday beer bash is impressive. Catered lunch and dinner if you stay past 7PM is also good. Nice offices (open floor plan). Good location, easy to commute to. Excellent place for recent grads as the pay scale is a bit low for the region. Extremely engineering centric which is good for engineers, not so great for everybody else. Not really a sweat shop; I saw very few engineers in on Saturday or Sunday.
cons: Antiquated management. No concern for career development. Limited communication downwards. Lot's of attention paid to acquiring new talent, very little paid to retaining existing talent. Company is too large now for new hires to make anything off stock options if the company ever goes public. This is a typical 'negative feedback' company. You will not get positive feedback when you do a good job but you will get negative feedback when you do a poor job. Communication between departments almost non-existent.

headline: Great company, although better when I joined
pros:
Working with really smart people around.

Some pioneer work on big data. Good reputation in big data community (at least I think).

cons: Sometimes feel management decisions unpredictable like black boxes. Long hours of working for some teams.

Overall benefits are competitive.

Exec team is short-sighted and one is driven so exclusively by his ego that it has caused the rapid unraveling the fabric of the formerly amazing corporate culture.
The execs appear to believe that the path to success is in following whatever footsteps Google made regardless of the circumstances.
Execs worship the engineers and all other teams are understaffed, overworked, underpaid and considered unimportant therefore not listened to.

headline: Great Culture

lots of egos on the executive team with decisions being made in a vacuum
they do the difficult things well, and the easy things badly

headline: A great place to build a career
pros: The people are sharp and focused on getting things done well.  Advertising technology is great field to work in.  It's evolving fast and provides a river of fresh and interesting problems to solve, both technical and otherwise.  You can be part of the reinvention of a $500B industry.  Quantcast is small enough yet important enough that what you do really matters.
cons: Expect to pull your weight.  The team works hard, supports each other, and gets a lot done.  You can succeed through inspiration, perspiration or a mix of the two, but if you're used to a relaxed pace of meetings-about-meetings, it may not be right for you.

headline: Exciting, challenging and rewarding experience at a progressive technology company.
pros: Smart people, great technology, advancing advertising.
cons: Great company, no complaints here.

headline: Fast Paced, incredibly informative, great training
pros: Overall company culture is outstanding.
cons: Sales department treated poorly and regarded as second class citizens in an engineering company. Salary is far below industry standards in digital media. High turnover - cannot maintain successful senior reps.

headline: Account Executive role review
pros: I have worked at Quantcast for over a year now, and am extremely pleased with my experience here. On the sales team, we are led by managers who have a wealth of knowledge in the industry and are very supportive of personsal growth and development. We also have three full time trainers that lead weekly sessions on sales tactics. Beyond impressive management and growth, the people are Quantcast are one of the best assets. For a sales team, it is not a cut-throat environment. You are motivated by the people around you, who are smart and hard working, to do your best.
cons: There is definitely a "ramp up" period for this role. I came in with no sales or industry background, and it took a good 3-6 months to get a grasp on the sales cycle (it is long and heavy on education) and to start exceeding quota. Once you understand the process however, you come to enjoy the educational and relationship building piece that goes with such a young, fast-paced growing and changing industry. The ramp up period forced me to develop sales skills that will be transferrable to whatever career I end up in the future.

headline: Do not join the Sales Team
pros: Awesome company (especially if you're an Engineer).  Intelligent, fun, and supportive co-workers.  Catered lunches, dinners and happy hours.  All the perks of a start up.
cons: Horrible sales management (some of the managers are literally demeaning and verbally abusive), impossible goals to meet, everyone is paranoid that they will be let go due to not meeting goals (more so than normal sales departments), very hard to close sales  (they are also hiring more and more people- so the list of accounts to reach out to is smaller and smaller daily), whether cold calling works or not- you are required to make 30 cold calls a day, and x amount of pitches, and x amount of emails.

headline: Best Place I've Ever Worked
pros:
Good people - across the company there are great people to work with and some of the smartest people I've ever met.
Technology - Leading the industry and is making a difference.
Good compensation and great potential in the company's future.
Great culture and values.
cons: Start Up problems : Growing fast, constantly learning, and solving problems (AKA Good problems to have)

cons: Startup with a lot of new managers.

headline: Fast-growing and exciting place to work
pros:
Dynamic company in a dynamic industry
Hires the best of the best: bright and friendly coworkers
Industry-leading technology
cons: Not a small company anymore, but not yet a large company, it is to be seen how we will handle this delicate transition

headline: Amazing product, very smart and focused team, incredible organization
pros: Certainly the smartest people I have ever worked with. This is a company focused on growing, disrupting, and changing the digital ad landscape. Incredibly fun culture with the right amount of work/life balance.
cons: Fast pace, figure it out as we grow technology start up. Things are changing, evolving, growing developing and will continue to do so for the quite some time. If that is exciting, and you work well with moving targets and and evolving workforce and infrastructure then you will thrive. If change is scary, or you need a manual for everything you do this will not be a good fit.

headline: The smartest people I've ever worked with
pros: Brilliant minds, youthful energy, professional people. Each organization within the company builds top-notch programs. Completely trust the executive leadership's vision.
cons: Growing fast, so quickly running out of room, but expanding into new space soon.

headline: Future Great Place to Work
pros:
No limits on the opportunities, we are growing at scale with a product that companies want to use.
We get well looked after in terms of a great benefits package and a really good salary & options package.
It is the chance to get in early into something that is going to be really successful
cons: It is such a start up that a lot of the structures are not in place and it is possible to end up doing 50 different things but that is part of the charm of a start up.

headline: Lots of interesting work. Great people. Some management issues.
pros:
- If you are in one of the engineering teams you'll be working with really smart people. The hiring bar is quite high. Overall, the coworkers are great and like to have fun. 
- Interesting problems to work on.  They will keep you motivated. 
- Generally, the technical leads will give you lot of freedom in your work and are very open to suggestions.
- Quantcast is an ideal place for young straight out-of-school engineers.
- Delicious catered food. Happy hour. Beer carts.
- The company is growing and doing very well.
- Konrad (CEO) is a smart guy and does great work.
cons:
- Management communication style is very closed. 
- Some teams have broad and undefined set of responsibilities. They lack focus. Makes working chaotic. 
- A few teams are over-worked and have high attrition rates. One of the ways management tries to solve this problem is by offering a monthly cash award which is rotated among members of all teams. It does very little to solve the underlying issues. 
- Considerable amont of technical debt. Management needs to address this concern. 
- Management does not do enough to gain feedback from employees. Non existent 1:1 meetings with managers. Not enough importance is given to career development. 
- Compensation is lower than market standards. Promotions are hard to come by. Quantcast has a very good referral policy rewarding successful referrals with multiple thousand dollars. But management does not feel it is necessary to offer promotions with similar rewards.

headline: Great place to grow your career by throwin' yourself right into it!
pros:
Lunch & Dinner catered (its a great perk if you don't focus on why they actual provide this perk)
Great place Great place to figure out what your bottom line is around the number of hours you're expected to put in regularly.  
Employers will value your experience here!
cons:
Expect 60+ hour weeks
Finance is a joke.
Poor HR representation

headline: Don't join the sales team
pros: The only pro is if you are on the engineering team - then you are treated like gold. Plus you can always get a better job after Quantcast - new employers love it!
cons: The cons are purely against being in the sales department. It is ran horribly. You are treated like a drone. There are minimum cold calls and emails per day. There is no encouragement and only putting the team down. People are pushed to eat at their desks and to work 12hr days for little to no money. When you walk on the sales floor you will know that everyone is unhappy.

headline: Great company, incredibly difficult to break new business
pros:
good start up culture
smart co workers
extensive training
good comp and great benefits
cons: company is expanding too fast, too hard to break and retain new business in a saturated market.  Many reps not making goal and/ or commission.  Free-for-all with no territory or verticals.

headline: Typical all around startup
pros:
- Bright group of folks in all departments company wide
- Cool technology stack
- Fun place to work, great location downtown
- Good perks. Good parties. Good people
cons:
- Long hours, if you're in Engineering or IT. Be prepared to work 60 hour weeks. 
- Continuous tight deadlines means it's always crunch time
- Some groups seem to have things together as a team, while others struggle at times due to fundamentals that management just chooses to ignore.

headline: Best working experience so far
pros:
1. Extremely smart group of engineers who deliver results and know how to have fun
2. Management is open to suggestions and new ideas, transparency has been getting better and better
3. It feels like a family, people are very connected across all departments
4. Ridiculous lunch cater who is creative and BBQed a whole pig the other day for Euro Cup
cons:
Office space is getting very crowded, hopefully it will be addressed by the new space they got.
Since the office is wide open, it can be noisy and hard to concentrate sometimes.
Meeting rooms are not sound proof, and you can hear people talking during meeting from outside

headline: Fantastic.
pros: They have an intelligent staff, a competitive product, and a great corporate environment.  A few of the highlights are: catered meals, catered happy hour on Fridays, book club, biking club, fully stocked kitchen, fully stocked supply room, company outings (baseball games, movies, etc). The best part has been meeting such interesting people at lunch and dinner. They have put together a fantastic staff and kept them happy.
cons: They are growing a little too quickly, there aren't enough employees to handle the work load.  However, they are aware of this and are hiring as quickly as they can.

headline: Smart people, fun place to work.
pros: Quantcast does a great job of hiring smart people. Almost everyone who works there, including managment is highly technical. There's a real focus on getting things done without a lot of bureaucratic overhead. Conventional wisdom is always questioned, and using the "industry standard" solution for anything requires making a case that it's still the best way.
cons: Open plan work environment is noisy and distracting.

headline: Okay place to work
pros:
1. Big engineering challenges
2. Smart engineering team
3. Coworkers are fun to work with
cons:
1. Not so competitive pay
2. Weird culture gap between rank&file employees and the management. If you are looking for a culture like lots of YC  companies, don't bother 
3. HR had done a terrible job in retaining talent. They are good at selling the company when recruiting, but doesn't care much once you are in. They tried to 'manufacture' a cool startup culture, but with the wrong mentality, it never really worked. Just ask them why most people on the photo which was taken when the company won the 'most innovative company' left, including the amazingly smart CTO.
4. Weak PM, sometimes I even wondered why we have a PM team.

headline: Amazing opportunity to contribute to interesting problems with awesome people
pros:
1) Cutting edge everything - you can get practical experience in real-time processing, filesystems, hadoop, etc
2) Awesome people
3) Good culture- chill but hardworking
4) Easy to move around if you wish to join a different team
5) Great perks - catered lunch and dinner
6) Great location
cons:
1) For some people it might be a bit too corporate, by which I mean it is not a tiny startup anymore and there do need to be some 'processes' which is deadly for those who like zero constraints on commits, etc that you might get at a small startup

2) I think people can be a little too focused on compensation as a reason to work and put in extra effort. That sounds naive, but in some places the internal reason might be 'wanting to change the world' etc but in the internet advertising space, that is just not going to be the case

3) Friends/Steve Yegge/family potentially regard the company as not a Good Thing to be doing / kind of sketchy. It really is not (although I admit the personal bias) but you may have some awkward conversations

headline: Professional, cutting-edge place to work
pros: There are a lot of smart people working at a lot of good companies, but what has made Quantcast different is the level of genuine cooperation among very talented individuals around common goals.  This is much harder said than done.  The result is that it's clear what you're working on and why.  There is a great sense of purpose and optimism at Quantcast to carry out the company's shared vision.  There's a good balance between senior and junior talent.
cons: Quantcast is transitioning from a small to a mid-sized company.  There's some legacy that come with that but the management is visible in trying to adapt to the typical cultural and communication challenges that come with that.  It's also a fast-growing company which means that there's far more immediate opportunity than resources sometimes allow.  Overall, decisions are handled well but does mean having to be creative within constraints.

headline: good company with some issues
pros:
* First, please note that the recent burst of high ratings is due to internal recruiters asking employees to rate quantcast.  That doesn't mean they're lying, but keep that in mind.
* coworkers are great and hiring standards are high
* if you're on the right team, you do legitimately work on big data / hadoop.  None of the 16 node "clusters" that other companies claim; we use 1k+ node clusters on 100+ TB datasets.
* quantcast, as a company, is performing well
* the display ad space is growing and quantcast is on the cutting edge of the rtb market
* the ceo Konrad and the head of product Jag are very impressive people who do great work.  In fact the majority of the employees are great at their jobs, but Konrad and Jag stand out.

so, should you work here?
* if you'll be working on hadoop jobs, probably: you'll get a great practical education in parallel computing and a great chit on your resume
* it depends on the team; make sure you aren't one of the people talking to salesforce or writing etl logic
* financially it won't make you rich even if quantcast goes public, but you may learn a lot more here on the right team
cons:
* what you work on and how good the job is can vary quite wildly by team.  Our ops team is massively overworked and seems to burn out within 6 months and either quit or transfer, while other teams have great retention.
* some people do write massive hadoop jobs, but you might end up coding interface / workflow logic to interface with salesforce or an ad server.  This is neither interesting nor exciting.
* It's fair to say there are very exciting and interesting technologies being built inside quantcast, but the important question is if you will be working on them.
* though it varies by team, it's fair to say that managers take little interest in career development of employees.
* someone below claimed stock options are generous.  That's simply wrong.  Engineers hired now will get a stock option package that pays out roughly $120k after taxes per billion dollars earned in a liquidity event if fully vested.  Financially, you're probably better off going to Google.  Upper management also seems to massively overestimate the value of stock options and we've had a ton of turnover of people who made quantcast a worse company for leaving.
* most importantly... more than 1/2 the company has quit in the last 16 months since our previous employee photo.  Including the cto who is an amazing technologist.  Management rarely discusses this with employees and doesn't seem to care to retain people.  This is worst in the engineering department through true across the company.  To quantcast's credit, when engineers quit I was almost always really sad to see the person leave.  The majority were definitely not bad hires.  Plus,  with our internal hadoop variant there is an enormous learning curve for engineers and it really hurts when people who understand all the internal systems keep leaving.
* the only direct effort to increase retainment is by moving salary to bonus and not paying it out until late April so that if an employee leaves before then he or she effectively forfeits 10% of his or her salary for the previous year.

headline: Industry-Leading Technology Startup - if you are high-speed, low-drag, you will enjoy working here.
pros: Quantcast is led by a CEO with proven track history of success. The company has retained its relatively flat structure, resulting in approachable management and timely decision-making process. The company has industry-leading technology and continues to grow its intellectual property portfolio. As a startup, there are many opportunities to roll up your sleeves, try different things and work collaboratively with various teams. Individual contributions are transparent/tangible. The engineers are friendly, social and can work well with non-technical staff. Catered lunches and dinners are a definite plus.
cons: Although a secondary factor in accepting a position with the company, salary and benefits are not as competitive as other companies/startups I have worked for. That said, I expect this to change as the company grows and becomes even more profitable. The recruiting team is solid but there is lack of HR presence.

headline: Lots of Energy and Smart People At Quantcast!
pros: Quantcast employs very smart folks. If you are independent and confident employee, you will do well there. There is much opportunity to contribute and gain great experience. Most employees are dedicated and work hard.
cons: Not strong in HR, lack of leadership in HR. Quantcast would do well to add experience and strength here.

headline: Great work environment: young, friendly, dynamic, highly educated and innovative people
pros:
Quantcast is best for having:
- brilliant minds & expertise
- amazing products
- opportunity to learn from superiors how to deal with professional challenges 
- location
- fun (company events, happy hours)
cons: Sometimes, your work has to be delivered on a short term notice, due to the speed with which the changes occur in a start-up environment

headline: It's extremely rewarding that the revenue I'm bringing in has a huge impact on our start-ups bottom line!
pros:
- Positive & Collaborative Sales Management to guide you & take your drive to win to a higher level 
- What you sell ACTUALLY works in delivering new customers to our clients so you have proof that our technology works for their online advertising campaigns
- If you ask questions of your teammates, they are happy to help & share the buzzwords for verticals & success with other clients
- You will be part of a company that is flipping the traditional advertising model on its' head
cons:
- Branding of our company needs to be improved
- Other teams like operations should have more people to assist w/ the sales team
- the process of getting new clients on board can be improved

headline: Quantcast IS All the Great Things About a Start-up!
pros: Quantcast is a fun & energetic place to work. I look forward to coming to work each day. The employees are smart and get along really well. Quantcast puts a lot of effort into keeping its employees positive and happy. The company is dynamic and market-leading. Quantcast takes both change and forward movement very seriously. Senior management has a great depth of experience, and is approachable. Quantcast's CEO is world-class. The company has brilliant prospects. Quantcast is a place where you can learn and grow.
cons: Nothing uncommon for tech start-ups, the hours are long.

headline: Fast paced engineering driven workplace at the cutting edge of online targeted advertising in the heart of San Francisco
pros: Quantcast has some of the most technically competent engineers I have ever worked with.  This combined with the engineering driven nature of the company and the near flawless execution of its business objectives, makes Quantcast a phenomenal place to work.  It is very unusual to find this level of technical caliber north of Palo Alto.  With realtime systems processing upward of 400,000 transactions a second and peak data processing at 5 petabytes a day there is never a dull day at Quantcast.
cons: Being a fairly small company, the standard benefits package and yearly compensation are lacking.  Also work hours can be long.

headline: Quantcast is a great place to work at with many interesting problems and really smart people
pros:
Massive amounts of data. Lots of interesting and challenging problems. Fun company to work for right in the middle of downtown San Francisco. Good benefits and salary, free food every day for lunch/dinner. Sometimes we get breakfasts, but don't count on those..

The upper management is generally really motivated, smart, and accessible.
The CEO is awesome.
cons: Office space is a bit crowded. There's also not a lot of incentive to work really hard except for your personal satisfaction (which in my case is enough, but thought I'd put it out there). Interestingly, a lot of people stay long hours.
